stream_context.summary: Kaze works on 'Oily Boily Bay' (Course 11), focusing on bug-fixing and implementing new hydraulic piston platforms in an underground area to enhance its industrial theme. The stream includes a live technical collaboration with artist Biobak on texture optimization, discussions on game design philosophy, and revelations about future plans for a commercial game and a major YouTube sponsorship.

development_findings.summary: The project is in a bug-fixing phase in preparation for a full beta test. It is planned to have 15 courses, and Kaze estimates it's about 75-80% complete.
development_findings.quote: I'm going through all the levels from course one to the last person fixing all the bugs that have appeared so that we can beta test every single level.

development_findings.summary: Kaze's approach to the difficulty curve involves saving more complex and 'cool' platforming challenges for later levels, rather than artificially increasing difficulty.
development_findings.quote: I don't try to make the levels more difficult. I just put the threshold of how cool a jump has to be for it to be worth the difficulty lower... Let's put this jump into a later level.

development_findings.summary: Kaze demonstrates deep technical problem-solving by creating a non-standard 96x42 pixel texture to fit a complex asset from Biobak within the N64's strict 4KB texture memory limit.
development_findings.quote: This is the most cursed texture resolution I've ever seen... 96 by 42.

development_findings.summary: Kaze prefers sending players back to the hub on death because it feels more 'impactful,' believing that over-prioritizing lack of frustration can diminish a game's substance.
development_findings.quote: When you make things lose impact for the sake of making your game less frustrating, you are always shifting your game a little further towards the arbitrary playground style.

development_findings.summary: Progress on fixing certain visual elements, such as door animations, is blocked by the need for a custom quaternion animation tool being developed by team member Lilaa.
development_findings.quote: Until we have Lila's quaternion animation exporter, R.I.P. Lila, we cannot fix the doors.

development_findings.summary: The RTYI engine features custom warp objects with additional parameters for hitbox height and camera angle, and it boots directly into a 3D file select level to avoid wasting the player's time.

Kaze implemented new hydraulic piston platforms in the 'Oily Boily Bay' underground area to make it feel more like active, industrial machinery, working through culling and object update order bugs in the process.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses a strong dislike for modern game design, believing it aims to help players 'erase time' rather than provide meaningful experiences.
context_findings.quote: Modern game design is made for people that are depressed and just want to erase time. Not for people that want to go have an experience.

context_findings.summary: Kaze plans to develop a new, original commercial platformer in Unreal Engine and will launch a Kickstarter for it when RTYI is released.
context_findings.quote: Simultaneously with the release of Return to Yoshi's Island we are going to start a Kickstarter for this game in Unreal Engine and then we will make big money.

context_findings.summary: Kaze discusses the financial realities of being a YouTuber, noting a significant increase in ad revenue around Christmas and his willingness to take sponsorships from companies like Honkai Star Rail.
context_findings.quote: The ad revenue on YouTube is so high. I'm making bank around Christmas. Like, holy shit. You suddenly just get a 50% pay raise if you are a YouTuber.

context_findings.summary: Kaze feels confident he won't have a midlife crisis because he believes he has already achieved a lot in his life.
context_findings.quote: I don't think I will ever have a midlife crisis. Isn't that when you're like 40 and you were like 'oh man I actually didn't achieve shit in my life'? I already achieved so much in my life.

context_findings.summary: Kaze differentiates his YouTube content strategy, using his main channel for high-value videos to maintain engagement and a second channel for more frequent, lower-effort updates.
Kaze has recently moved into a house with his spouse, Zeina.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided a high-resolution sail texture that exceeded N64 memory limits, prompting a real-time collaboration with Kaze to find a workable, albeit unconventional, texture compression solution.
biobak.quote: Does this work for you, Biobak? This is the most cursed texture resolution I've ever seen. I think it works.

zeina.summary: Zeina confirms Kaze's memory of a lost 'Hot Tub Mario' mod he created, indicating her long-term awareness of and involvement in his modding history.

key_stories.title: The Cursed Texture Solution
key_stories.summary: Artist Biobak created a texture that was too large for the N64's memory. Kaze collaborated with him live on stream, devising a 'cursed' non-standard texture resolution as a clever workaround to fit the asset into the game, showcasing the technical creativity required for the project.
key_stories.challenge: A high-resolution sail texture provided by artist Biobak exceeded the N64's 4KB texture memory limit, making it unusable in its original form.
key_stories.process: Kaze analyzed the memory usage, realized standard texture sizes wouldn't work, and experimented with non-power-of-two dimensions. He calculated a 'cursed' resolution that would fit within the memory budget and confirmed the approach with Biobak during the stream.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully implemented the asset by creating a highly unconventional 96x42 pixel texture, demonstrating a practical solution to the extreme hardware constraints of the N64.
key_stories.key_quote: This is the most cursed texture resolution I've ever seen. I think it works.

key_stories.title: The 'Death' and Return of Lilaa
key_stories.summary: When animator Lilaa was absent for a week, Kaze and the community jokingly declared her dead, holding a mock funeral on stream. Her return in the chat turned into a humorous moment that highlighted the team's informal dynamic and their reliance on her specialized animation tools.
key_stories.challenge: Key animator Lilaa was absent from the community for a week, leading to a mix of genuine concern for her well-being and a dependency on her for a critical animation tool.
key_stories.process: Kaze and the community started a running joke that Lilaa had died. Kaze made a mock 'R.I.P. Lilaa' post on Discord and held a fake 'burial' on stream. When she reappeared, he and the chat explained the joke to her.
key_stories.outcome: Lilaa returned to the stream chat, saw the joke, and took it in stride. The incident revealed the team's playful, dark sense of humor and highlighted the critical dependency on her custom-built quaternion animation tool for the project's progress.
key_stories.key_quote: We all thought you died, Lilaa. We had a whole burial for you earlier during the stream.

key_stories.title: The Lost Mod and the Sponsorship Plan
key_stories.summary: Kaze discovered a risqué mod he once made is now lost media. After receiving a lucrative sponsorship offer, he embraces a viewer's suggestion to release the lost mod as the sponsored content, seeing it as a funny, 'insane' idea that would troll Nintendo.
key_stories.challenge: While discussing past work, Kaze realized a risqué mod he made called 'Hot Tub Mario 64' was never publicly released and had become lost media.
key_stories.process: Kaze and Zeina recalled the mod but couldn't find it anywhere. A viewer then suggested releasing the lost mod as part of a high-paying sponsorship he was considering. Kaze immediately latched onto the idea as a perfect, humorously provocative plan.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze enthusiastically decided to pitch the idea of releasing the lost mod as the sponsored video for Honkai Star Rail, viewing it as a hilarious and lucrative way to fulfill the brand deal.
key_stories.key_quote: Release it for the Honkai Sponsorship? Oh, that is so insane. That is such a good idea.

open_questions.context: Kaze announced plans to create a demo for a new, original platformer in Unreal Engine and launch a Kickstarter for it when RTYI releases. He has ideas but is keeping them private.
questions: What lessons from the constraints of N64 ROM hacking do you believe will be most valuable when working with the freedom of a modern engine like Unreal?
What is the core concept for this new game that gives you the confidence to plan a Kickstarter campaign around it?
How do you plan to manage the RTYI community post-release while simultaneously launching a major new commercial project?

open_questions.context: Kaze stated that fixing door animations is impossible until Lilaa finishes her custom 'quaternion animation exporter' tool.
questions: What specific technical limitations of the original SM64 animation system does a quaternion-based tool solve?
Can you describe the collaborative process of developing custom engine tools with team members like Lilaa?
How has the need for such custom tools impacted the project's timeline and overall design?

open_questions.context: Kaze expressed a strong opinion against 'modern game design,' stating it's for people who want to 'erase time' and that he prefers creating 'impactful' experiences, even if they are more frustrating.
questions: Could you elaborate on what you mean by an 'arbitrary playground style' of game?
Besides the death mechanic, what are other examples in RTYI where you've prioritized 'impact' over reducing 'frustration'?
Do you see a conflict between this design philosophy and creating a game that a 'bad audience' can still enjoy?

open_questions.context: Kaze was offered a potentially lucrative sponsorship from Honkai Star Rail and plans to create a video for his main channel, possibly featuring a lost, risqué mod.
questions: How do you navigate the balance between your creative integrity and the financial necessity of sponsorships?
What are your thoughts on the potential reaction from Nintendo, especially given their new guidelines, to you releasing a provocative mod as part of a major sponsorship?
You mentioned hating making videos but needing to keep the channel alive. How does this tension shape the content you decide to produce?
